descriptions.content:
Like other modal verbs, this one goes after the main verb and before the auxiliary. The tense of the main verb may be the present-future or the past–either will do. The verb ཆོག་ is used mainly in with the future auxiliaries: ཆོག་གི་རེད་ for future and present situations. However, other auxiliaries are sometimes used: ཆོག་གི་འདུག་ (testimonial present), ཆོག་གི་ཡོད་རེད་ (assertive present). The combinations are sometimes used in the past, but never occur with intentional egophoric auxiliaries; for instance, *ཆོག་པ་ཡིན་ and *ཆོག་གི་ཡིན་ are incorrect.

The verb ཆོག་ has two meanings: The first, and more usual meaning, is “to be allowed” or “may”; secondly, it can also have the meaning “to be able” or “can” in which case it can be substituted by ཐུབ་.

  • ཁ་བཏགས་ཁྲོམ་ནས་ཉོས་ཆོག་གི་རེད། “We can buy khatak in the market.”
  • ལྷ་ཁང་ནང་ལ་པར་བརྒྱབ་ཆོག་གི་རེད་པས། “Are we allowed to take photos inside the temple?”
